entry.title: Numbers that a programmer should know
entry.content:
When we talk about profession for a progrommer, I believe this is one of the area that a programmer should also take into consideration.

  • Notice the magnitude differences in the performance of different options.
  • Datacenters are far away so it takes a long time to send anything between them.
  • Memory is fast and disks are slow.
  • By using a cheap compression algorithm a lot (by a factor of 2) of network bandwidth can be saved.
  • Writes are 40 times more expensive than reads.
  • Global shared data is expensive. This is a fundamental limitation of distributed systems. The lock contention in shared heavily written objects kills performance as transactions become serialized and slow.
  • Architect for scaling writes.
  • Optimize for low write contention.
  • Optimize wide. Make writes as parallel as you can.

entry.title: Save as root in vim
entry.content:
Its been a while, as I am busy drawing for my game :P

This is handy when you forgot to do sudo vim

:w !sudo tee %

:w – Write a file. !sudo – Call shell sudo command. tee – The output of write (vim :w) command redirected using tee. The % is nothing but current file name i.e. /etc/apache2/conf.d/mediawiki.conf. In other words tee command is run as root and it takes standard input and write it to a file represented by %. However, this will prompt to reload file again (hit L to load changes in vim itself):

entry.title: Am I "Cloud"
entry.content:
I read an article, that is about the demanding for Cloud Engineer has significantly increased over the past few years.

The first thing that came to my mind, what is Cloud Engineer?

After google around, it seems the first thing that you need to know what is SaaS, Software as a Service.

With the emerging and maturing of CSS3, HTML5 and JavaScript, there has been a lot of SaaS providers running now in the market, popular providers such as GitHub, Google Doc, Google Drive, DropBox and etc.

Now, I am asking myself, am I Cloud?

For one second, I wish to be the Cloud Strife in Final Fantasy 7, cool, smart, strong and brave.

I have been using DropBox and Box as my storage media.

I have using GitHub as my blog, can I call myself Cloud Blogger?

I am using Google Doc for my office work.

Well, I guess I am only considered as Cloud …. user and not a Cloud Engineer, hey, wait a second…., I am developing my game on AWS.

I would definitely dig more into Cloud Engineer as I want to be Cloud.

entry.title: Bitbucket vs. GitHub
entry.content:
Just came across this article at the end of the work.

Sounds interesting on the comparison in service and pricing, which might be a good idea to look back when I want to host my source code in the future ( although I hosted personally for now ….).

In summary that caught my eyes in the article,

We ended up using both GitHub and Bitbucket to get the best of both worlds. For our private repositories, we use Bitbucket because the pricing model is so much smarter for us. With Bitbucket we pay about $30 a month as opposed to the $200 we’d be paying at GitHub. When we have some code we want to share with the community, we’ll send the repository over to GitHub for wider exposure.

entry.title: Speed up with base64 images
entry.content:
A very challenging task in web-based game is to get the images download to the player browser client.

As we all know that, using either CSS background-image with URL, JavaScript Image object or HTML <img> tag requires the browser client to initiate new HTTP call for every image download.

Why is this a bad idea?

Every new initiated HTTP call download perform the standard TCP connection and that is heavy, especially in mobile environement as it utilized more processing power.

Besides that, it is much much slower that you can imagine.

Lastly, the request for image download does choke up your websever.

Following is an image showing the number of connections and time spent.

Base64 Image
